{{Infobox military unit |unit_name=The Rangers |image= |caption= |dates=1860-1960s |allegiance={{flag|United Kingdom}} |branch={{army|United Kingdom}} |command_structure= |type=[[Infantry]] |role=[[Territorial Army (United Kingdom)|Territorial Army]] |size=[[Battalion]] |current_commander= |garrison= |ceremonial_chief= |ceremonial_chief_label= |colonel_of_the_regiment= |colonel_of_the_regiment_label= |Phone_number= |motto= |colors= |identification_symbol_2= |identification_symbol_2_label= |identification_symbol= |identification_symbol_label= |march= |mascot= |battles= |notable_commanders= |anniversaries= }}
'''The Rangers''' was a [[Volunteer Force (United Kingdom)|volunteer]] unit of the [[British Army]], originally formed in 1860.
==Volunteer Force 1860–1908== The Rangers were first raised at [[Gray's Inn]] on 30 April 1860 as the 40th Middlesex Rifle Volunteer Corps (Central London Rangers), a [[rifle volunteers|rifle volunteer]] unit forming part of the 3rd Administrative Battalion with the 39th Middlesex Rifle Volunteer Corps (the future Finsbury Rifles). It became the 22nd Middlesex Rifle Volunteer Corps (Central London Rangers) in 1880 and a volunteer battalion of the [[King's Royal Rifle Corps]] (KRRC) the following year.<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20060104211026/http://www.regiments.org/regiments/uk/volmil-london/vinf/L12rangr.htm regiments.org – The Rangers]</ref><ref name="Beckett2007">{{cite book|author=Ian F. W. Beckett|title=Riflemen Form: A Study of the Rifle Volunteer Movement 1859–1908|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=olR-AwAAQBAJ&pg=PA60|date=30 July 2007|publisher=Pen and Sword|isbn=978-1-84415-612-2|pages=60, 111–112, 161, 190}}</ref>
In 1891 it underwent a slight renaming as the 22nd Middlesex Volunteer Rifle Corps (Central London Rangers).
==History== On the formation of the [[Territorial Force]] in 1908 the Rangers became the 12th (County of London) Battalion of the new [[London Regiment]]. On the outbreak of [[World War I]] in August 1914 it formed part of [[169th (3rd_London) Brigade|3rd London Brigade]] within [[56th (London) Infantry Division|1st London Division]].<ref>[http://www.1914-1918.net/krrc.htm The Long Long Trail – King's Royal Rifle Corps]</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Navy and Army Illustrated|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2Kc_AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA290|year=1904|page=290}}</ref> It was mobilised and moved to [[Bullswater]], then to [[Crowborough]] in September and [[Roehampton]] in December. In the interim, during October 1914, it was assigned to guard Waterloo-North Camp (Aldershot) railway.
On 25 December 1914 it left its division on landing at [[Le Havre]]. On 8 February 1915 it was put under the command of [[84th Brigade (United Kingdom)|84th Brigade]] within [[28th Division (United Kingdom)|28th Division]]. It was transferred to GHQ Troops on 20 May to form a composite unit with the London Regiment's 1/5th and 1/13th Battalions–that only lasted until 11 August, when the three battalions regained their original identity. On 12 February 1916 it was moved into [[168th (2nd London) Brigade|168th Brigade]] within [[56th (London) Infantry Division|56th (London) Division]]. The unit was formally transferred to the corps of the KRRC on 7th July 1916, though it also remained a battalion of the [[London Regiment]] until 1937, when it was renamed The Rangers, The King's Royal Rifle Corps. It switched brigades on 31 January 1918, moving to [[175th (2/3rd London) Brigade|175th Brigade]] within [[58th (2/1st London) Division|58th Division]]–at the same time it absorbed its duplicate battalion, 2/12th Battalion, which had been formed in September 1914.
A duplicate 2nd Battalion was formed again on 31 March 1939, leading the original unit to add 1st Battalion to its name.
Upon the outbreak of [[World War II]] in September 1939 both battalions were part of the [[169th (3rd_London) Brigade|3rd London Brigade]].
On 22 March 1941, while serving with the [[20th Armoured Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|20th Armoured Brigade]], became the 9th Battalion, King's Royal Rifle Corps (The Rangers).
In 1947 the battalion became The Rangers, The Rifle Brigade (Prince Consort's Own).
==Post war== In 1960 the Rangers amalgamated with the [[London Rifle Brigade]] to form London Rifle Brigade/Rangers, whose successor unit, after continuous service as Royal Green Jackets, is G Company of the 7th Battalion the Rifles, who are based at the Army Reserve Centre, The Cedars, Portway, West Ham, London E15 3QN
==References== <references/>
